physDesc.p: This letter is three pages long. Aldington's address is typed in the heading on the top left of the front page: Richard Aldington, Esq., Malthouse Cottage, Padworth, Reading, Berks, England. On the following pages, “Mr. Aldington – [pg #]” is typed on the right side of the heading. “Ok” is written in pencil in the upper right corner of the first two pages. Included is a certificate of issue for $4.95, dated November 14, 1923. “Richard Aldington” is written in pencil on the back of the receipt. There is a large tear on the left side of the first page and several smaller tears on the right side of the front page.

I should have sent them as long ago as August, and I feel very guilty indeed to have kept them so long. That [illegible] is I feel [illegible] little better, but I have no other excuse whatever except pressure of business on this Keats book. Please forgive me.

It seems so long since I have heard from you that I feel quite out of touch with you. You must write me and tell me how things are going with you. I have seen poems of yours now and then in various American periodicals; particularly in the “Literary Review.” That is by far the best literary paper we have, and I am awfully glad to see you in it, both in prose and in poetry, as often as I do. I heard of Harriet Monroe's having had a glimpse of you. I should like to know your impression of that somewhat tightly bound little lady.

Once again I have had to postpone my going to England. My Keats book is not done, but will be shortly. I think, however, that in order to get it through the press I shall have to stay here this Summer. It really seems as though I should never cross the ocean again, but, of course, that is nonsense, and I shall soon be free to go wherever I please. I have done nothing for six months but write the Keats book, which I hope will justify my effort upon it. It is very long, and very fully documented, and it will certainly be a contribution to scholarship, if nothing else. I have found
such a lot of new things, and in the light of new discoveries have been able to re-date poems and a lot of other things of this kind.

Do write and tell me your news. I imagine you know the American situation quite as well as I do. A group younger than ourselves, in fact two groups, have sprung up; the first is extremely expert in the old-fashioned type of verse, and the other, a set of young people who call themselves “Secessionists,” approach somewhat to the Dada type of thing. The work of both groups is very different from ours, and I cannot think any of it as good. Meanwhile, all the older poets keep on writing just the same, and as none of the younger ones have been able to surpass them on their own ground they still hold the supremacy. I have about two books of poems in manuscript – possibly three – ready to be collected as soon as the Keats book is off my hands. The first is a book of Yankee poems like “The Overgrown Pasture” section in “Men, Women and Ghosts.” It is to be called “East Wind,” but will not appear until a year from next Autumn, because the Keats book is scheduled for next Autumn.

I saw Fletcher when he was over here last Spring for a little while, but I have not heard from him since. We have gone off somewhat at a tangent in our literary practice which makes reasons for writing less frequent. I had some telephones from Lawrence when he was here, but he did not succeed in getting over to Boston to stay with me. I cannot help thinking that his work is deteriorating; he is writing too much and too often and is rather losing his prestige in consequence. You know he had a big boom over here.
I hear that your friend T. S. Eliot is rather better in health, but that his wife has been very ill, which is a shame.
As I said before, do write and tell me all your news. I am awfully anxious to hear it. I am sending Flint's draft with yours, as, of course, I do not know where he is.
